prop.head.headtext: Confidential Business Information and the Employment Relationship

head.headtext: Severance and Reading Down of Restrictive Covenants

para.paratext: Since it is often difficult to determine what the courts will consider to be a reasonable covenant, many employers make use of a series of clauses or subclauses which outline different geographical restraints and scopes of prohibited activity. The purpose of such clauses is to allow the court to decide what is reasonable without causing the entire covenant to be unenforceable.[1] The courts will “sever” restrictive covenants as long as the integrity of those covenants can be maintained.[2] However, the courts will not “revise” or rewrite such covenants.[3]
In Gautreau v. Arvelo,[4] the court stated:

The Plaintiff submitted that the court should simply read the clause down to what in the court's view would be reasonable. In my view, I ought not to do so where this would be tantamount to rewriting the parties' contract. In Crain-Drummond Inc. v. Hamel (1991), 35 C.C.E.L. 55 (Ont. Gen. Div.), Charron J., as she then was, dealt with a non-solicitation clause which provided as follows:

It is agreed that the Employee shall not for a period of one year after the termination of his employment solicit orders from any customer(s) of the Company and/or its subsidiaries in the territories to which he has been assigned as sales representative of the Company.
She identified problems with this clause … and found that she could not read the clause down without rewriting the agreement:

The plaintiff submits that the court may read out portions of a covenant it finds offending and enforce the rest: Investors Syndicate Ltd. v. Versatile Investments Inc. (1983), 73 C.P.R. (2d) 107 (Ont. C.A.). While this can be done in an appropriate case, it cannot be done where, as in this case, it would require the court to rewrite the agreement for the parties.
So also, in J.G. Collins Insurance Agencies Ltd., supra, the Supreme Court of Canada stated at pages 7 and 8:

The fact that it could have been drafted in narrower terms would not have saved it, for as Viscount Haldane said in Mason v. Provident Clothing and Supply Co., supra, p. 732, “… the question is not whether they could have made a valid agreement but whether the agreement actually made was valid.”

In Community Credit Union Ltd. v. Ast,[5] the Alberta Court of Queen's Bench held that the fact that a ladder-type covenant in an employment agreement gives rise to a host of optional outcomes does not render it unreasonably broad or vague. The court severed the covenants it found to be overly restrictive in order to render the restrictive covenant reasonable with respect to duration and geographical scope. It also severed a clause purporting to waive any defences to the reasonableness of the restrictive covenant, noting that it was inconsistent with the objective intentions of the parties and it was unlikely that such a clause would ever be enforceable for public policy reasons.

The 2009 decision of the Supreme Court of Canada in Shafron v. KRG Insurance Brokers (Western) Inc.[6] provides that restrictive covenants will no longer be read down to cure defects unless an objective “bright line” test exists to distinguish what is legal from what is not. Employers should not be invited to draft overly broad restrictive covenants with the prospect that the court will sever the unreasonable parts or read down the covenant to what the courts consider reasonable.

At this trial level in KRG Insurance Brokers (Western) Inc. v. Shafron,[7] an employee signed employment contracts in which he agreed not to be employed in the insurance brokerage business within the “Metropolitan City of Vancouver” for three years. The British Columbia Court of Appeal relied on the Supreme Court of Canada decision in Transport North American Express Inc. v. New Solutions Financial Corp.[8] to hold that severance can be used to read down restrictive covenants to cure illegality, as long as the legitimate intentions of the parties are respected. The British Columbia Court of Appeal interpreted the restrictive covenant to mean that the employee was prevented from working in the insurance brokerage business in the City of Vancouver and municipalities contiguous to it.

The Supreme Court of Canada reversed the decision of the British Columbia Court of Appeal and restored the trial decision, holding that the phrase “Metropolitan City of Vancouver” was ambiguous and thus unenforceable. The court held that notional severance cannot be applied to a restrictive covenant. The onus is on the party seeking to enforce the restrictive covenant to show that it is reasonable and a party seeking to enforce an ambiguous covenant will be unable to demonstrate reasonableness.

The Supreme Court noted that restrictive covenants in employment contracts are scrutinized more rigorously than restrictive covenants in the sale of a business because there is often an imbalance in power between employees and employers and because a sale of a business often involves a payment for goodwill whereas no similar payment is made to an employee leaving his or her employment.[9]

Notional severance (reading down a provision in a contract to make it enforceable) is therefore not an appropriate way to cure a defective restrictive covenant except where an objective “bright line” test exists to distinguish what is legal from what is not. Employers should not be invited to draft overly broad restrictive covenants with the prospect that the court will sever the unreasonable parts or read down the covenant to what the courts consider reasonable.[10]

See Orlan Karigan and Associates Ltd. v. Hoffman (2001), 5 C.C.E.L. (3d) 311 (Ont. S.C.J.), where the court held that an entire clause containing both non-competition and non-solicitation provisions was unenforceable.

Nelson Burns & Co. v. Gratham Industries Ltd. (1983), 150 D.L.R. (3d) 692, 42 O.R. (2d) 705 (H.C.J.), affd 30 D.L.R. (4th) 158n, 55 O.R. (2d) 426n (C.A.), leave to appeal to S.C.C. refused 56 O.R. (2d) 604n, 18 O.A.C. 238n. See also the discussion of the doctrine of severance in Transport North American Express Inc. v. New Solutions Financial Corp., [2004] 1 S.C.R. 249, and ACS Public Sector Solutions Inc. v. Courthouse Technologies Ltd. (2005), 262 D.L.R. (4th) 512 (B.C.C.A.).

See Canadian American Financial Corp. (Canada) Ltd. v. King (1989), 60 D.L.R. (4th) 293, 36 B.C.L.R. (2d) 257 (C.A.), where the court held that restrictive covenants will not be rewritten to make them reasonable. Hub International (Richmond Auto Mall) Ltd. v.
